descriptionSet.description: The image shows Bollywood actress Suraiya dressed glamorously in a shiny sari and wearing earrings and a necklace. On the lower right corner one can see an illustration of Lux toilet soap.

inscription.text: The beauty soap of the film stars

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Suraiya
text-en: January 1954 February
text-en: The beauty soap of the film stars
text-en: LUX TOILET SOAP

description-en: The image shows Bollywood actress Suraiya dressed glamorously in a shiny sari and wearing earrings and a necklace. On the lower right corner one can see an illustration of Lux toilet soap. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Besides Suraiya, this calendar features Meena Kumari, Kamini Kaushal, Krishna Kumari, Shashikala and Rehana. The first three names among them were well established actresses in Bombay cinema. All these women had started work at approximately the same time and they all had important films around 1954. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: After a series of flops in the fifties, Suraiya had starred in Waris and the popular Mirza Ghalib in 1954. Her singing and performance as a courtesan in Mirza Ghalib would be highly acclaimed and the film was awarded the President’s Gold Medal. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: One of the longest running campaigns the world over, Lux, an international venture of Levers Brothers, featured Hollywood stars in most parts of the world. This is not surprising since Hollywood was the only global film industry at the time. Lux entered India in 1929 and while its early advertisements would feature Hollywood actresses, they would eventually be replaced almost completely by local stars. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Marked by its use of the portraiture of known faces, Lux can be seen as one of the earliest forms of celebrity endorsements. As an extra cinematic site that showcased female stardom for its consumers, the repetitive advertisement could also be situated within practices of cinephilia. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)
related literature: Dyer, Richard and Christine Gledhill 2009. "Wanted: Cultured ladies Only! Female Stardom and Cinema in India 1930s-1950s". Urbana and Chicago: University of Illinois Press. (gs)
related literature: Gadihoke, Sabika 2010. "Selling Soap and Stardom: The Story of Lux" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/104/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-14 (gs)
related literature: McClintock, Anne 1995. "Imperial Leather. Race, Gender and Sexuality in the colonial contest." New York: Routlegde. (gs)
related literature: McClintock, Anne 2001. “Soft Soaping Empire: Commodity Racism and Imperial Advertising” in Double Crossings: Madness, Sexuality and Imperialism. Vancouver, Canada: Ronsdale. (gs)
related literature: Sivulka, Julianne 1998. "Soap, Sex and Cigarettes: A Cultural History of Advertising". Belmont, California: Wadsworth Publishing Co. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Many Indian actresses were featured in Indian advertisements for Lux Soap. From Madhuri Dixit and Hema Malini to Aishwarya Rai, Kareena Kapoor and Katrina Kaif. It seems as if Lux had and still has a big share of the Indian soap market. A nice overview of Lux vintage ads featuring Indian actresses can be found under http://8ate.blogspot.com/2009/09/vintage-lux-ads-beauty-soap-of-film.html .(la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: An interesting citation from the website of Unilever UK sheds light on their advertising rhetoric and why they have chosen this particular brand name: “Since the 1930s, over 400 of the world’s most stunning and sensuous women have been proudly associated with Lux advertisements. Marilyn Monroe, Brigitte Bardot, Demi Moore and, more recently, our own Catherine Zeta-Jones, have all been part of the Lux glamour story. (…) The name Lux means ‘light’ in Latin, however the name was chosen for its play on the word ‘luxury’”. Retrieved from http://www.unilever.co.uk/brands/personalcarebrands/lux.aspx, last accessed 2011-08-21 (la)
